pros: Autonomy, flexibility, good culture and good people.
cons: Small departments, workload can be a lot at times, biting off more than they can chew.

review_title: Great mission, but was frequently supplanted/undermined
pros: First great experience with a phenomenal culture on the surface. It was fabulous to get catered lunch on occasion, flexible working hours, no micro-managing. Fun people and very lax environment for full-time staff members. Cool travel opportunities that were always compensated upfront. The mission to 'level the playing field' and make education more equitable was very easy to get behind, and many of the people I worked with directly were visibly passionate about what we did for students. Many supervisors had been students in the program and had a personal conviction; they did their best to support us as employees. DEI efforts were made a priority during the time I served there, which was encouraging.
cons: No ladder for growth/leadership/better pay - which was the first big problem. Because we were a non-profit, there was a culture very similar to a small tech start-up, where folks "wear multiple hats" but are not compensated for their additional contribution or innovation for certain processes that ultimately made the ship run more smoothly. There was blatant favoritism at times and there was only one person leading HR at the time. High turnover rate for WOC. CEO would frequently travel and felt out-of-touch at times with privilege.

job_title: College Access Coach in Austin, TX
pros: You get to work on a flexible schedule with many paid time off hours. The supervisors are friendly and diverse and working with students can feel fulfilling.
cons: There is a lot of down time.

review_title: Challenging and Rewarding Experience for Young Professionals
pros: For context, I came to College Forward having worked at a couple other nonprofit organizations, which has certainly informed a lot of my experiences throughout my time at CoFo. I served as an AmeriCorps Coach for a year before joining on as a full-time staff member before leaving to grad school. My experience, which sits in contrast to some other recent comments, was filled with fulfilling work, a significant amount of autonomy, growth opportunities, student stories, and an all-around great staff. I was offered consistent access to senior staff members who made a point to keep their door open to us newer team members, two of whom wrote my recommendation letters for grad school. It was also evident that the organization was putting some material effort into their DEI, which seemed to be picking up steam as I was leaving. All in all, if you’re looking for a challenge, a lot of responsibility, and a potential long-term career in education, I recommend diving in.
cons: The organization definitely has a fast-paced culture that may not be a great fit if you’re looking for a more predictable and structured experience. With a number of other initiatives running, it can be hard to keep up with everything else going on outside of the core programming (things like policy and advocacy work, or a technology tool being used by other nonprofits).

pros:
Flexible Hours
Paid Time Off and company holidays
cons:
Toxic work culture
Low pay
Does not ascribe to its own values

pros: eh, not the worst place to work
cons: no growth from within, no contructive criticism

pros:
Challenging and service rewarding experience for Young Professionals. 
Treats employees fairly and accommodates to needs.
cons: Sometimes project-based work can get hectic based on how many employees are working on it at a time.

job_title: College Access Coach in Austin, TX
pros: Flexible, lots of energy, good stop over before the "real world"
cons: No real professional development, not welcoming to diverse points of view. You don't want to be a moderate or conservative here.

review_title: Great heart, bad head at the organization
job_title: College Program Access Manager in Austin, TX
pros: good work, good mission, good people (generally)
cons: misogyny, start up culture without the money, figurehead leader that is all about growth and not about quality

pros:
- Great opportunity to give back to community  and help students reach their goals and follow their dreams, while also growing during the process.
- I really enjoyed the ability to make the position  my own and use my previous experiences and passions as a tool to connect and deepen my relationships with my students! Managers do a good job of giving you a clear idea of what milestones need to be met both within the organization as well as with students - which later opened up opportunity to confidently bring in my own approach and skill into play.
- A vast variety of professional development opportunities are always in the mix - I appreciated and definitely made sure to attend as many in and out house trainings, events and public speaking opportunities. 
- I found College Forward to be very intentional and supportive in insuring the best possible future for their coaches - whether that be returning to serve as a coach for another year, attending grad school  or taking the next step into your career. 
-  Definitely a position that if proactive can lead to many more opportunities in the future - it is what you make it!
cons:
- AmeriCorps stipend low, but hey that's what you sign up for!
- Each caseload and each school will be ran differently and it is important to know and discuss beforehand how certain milestones/organizational goals would be better reached if the different school dynamics are discussed and made an importance. This can be frustrating when ignored.

review_title: Overworked and Directionless,  Despite Being a Well-Meaning Organization
pros: They have high impact for students that are engaged through the organization. There is ongoing trainings and engagement activities for staff and AmeriCorps members. There is a culture of continuous learning and collaboration between different teams. Program Managers are great at providing resources and support for AmeriCorps member professional development. HR team is great and systematic which allows for the hiring, onboarding, and employee management process to be very comprehensive and easy to understand. Staff gets a good amount of PTO and holidays. Medical benefits are comprehensive.
cons: I worked at the organization for 3 years and saw it go through a variety of strategic changes.  During this time there was a high amount of staff turnover. While the organization provided strong programming for the student population it served, they did not have a strong plan for capacity building for these programs. The existing programs took a backseat to new directions that we no longer student-focused.  There's a high level of burnout for staff and they did not have a sustainable plan to address the constant stress. Upper management tries to be open to feedback but is often unresponsive or slow to create any lasting improvements for their employees. Additionally, equity and diversity within the organization is a low-priority and brushed aside when brought up. The AmeriCorps members come in with a great purpose and willingness to create a lasting impact only to be jaded with the service provided.

review_title: Fantastic students and co workers, poorly run organization.
pros: If you're passionate about education or interested in the non-profit world, this is a fantastic way to get your feet wet and make professional connections before heading into your first job or onto higher education. The students and my coworkers were the silver lining to the job. I loved working with the students and getting to know them. It's obvious how appreciative the more engaged students are and how much they benefit from what the organization does.
cons: I was very disappointed in the leadership of the organization. There was an extremely high turnover rate and management did not work well together. It is true that they asked for coaches' input, but as a whole, the organization was slow to manage change and really could have benefited from an outside perspective rather than continually hiring internally. I'm fine with a bit of data entry, but the position was not at all challenging enough and definitely should not have qualified as a full-time position. Despite joining several work groups with the intent of getting more involved, I didn't feel like much got accomplished during my group meetings except everyone talking in circles with no results. As expected from any AmeriCorps position, the pay and benefits were low, so I recommend looking for outside part time jobs during your year of service.

pros: College Forward is a great place to put your passion. The vision is huge and the strategy is inspiring. There is lots of fascinating work to do at College Forward. Going to work is a real thrill because you can see the your individual projects moving the big picture. Those who are driven will find opportunities that they couldn't have imagined, responsibilities that they didn't think they were ready for, and a place for huge growth. The organization makes an unquestionable impact and the work is incredibly meaningful. It is a great place for someone new to the workforce to start their career, or for someone with more experience to test their limits.
cons: As a fast growing organization, lots can change very quickly. This can be confusing or disorienting at times, and it requires patience and a special kind of problem-solving to get the information you need. For admin staff, it is sometimes difficult to juggle work priorities and still make time to visit students.

review_title: The students are the only good thing
pros: as completion and access coaches you will work directly with students, $25 cellphone reimbursement(should be more), free medical insurance
cons: training is terribly inadequate for both completion and access coaches, a ridiculous amount of double work, backwards tasks(like practicing phone calls after a month of supervisors being around while you've called students), copilot is unorganized and they're continuously adding unnecessary things, the deadlines and milestones are illogical, they keep changing the rules for reimbursements so that they don't have to reimburse us, poor communication concerning everything(especially pay), convoluted google drive that has way too much and is unorganized, have to use personally while being on very low Americorps stipend to buy things for campus visits, reimbursement takes a month

review_title: Truly a disservice to students and Americorps members
pros: Working with some great students.
cons:
Don't let the snappy branding fool you, this is a terrible place to work and a morally bankrupt organization. 

Americorps members were treated like expendable tools. Communication was poor and often condescending. There was little skill building or professional development. For a low-paid learning experience, I came away with very little to add to my resume. Despite my best efforts, the relationships built with students felt transactional and hollow, they knew they would have a new coach the following year and that College Forward has few to no real community ties. 

The upper management of the organization reeks of faux-woke neoliberal emptiness. There may have been good intentions at some point, but by the time I was there it felt like the only purpose of organization was getting "Co-Pilot" off the ground (maybe they genuinely believe it's a helpful tool, a more sinister read is that they'll enjoy a nice fat Ed-Tech payday). What's most upsetting about all this is that it comes on the backs of Americorps members and students. For example, while I was there, there were tons of sessions teaching coaches to use salesforce but barley any attention paid to getting coaches trained up on teaching SAT/ACT prep or how to advise students on the massive financial decisions that college entails. Students deserve so much better than this. Their needs should be front and center, they simply are not.

job_title: CoFo Access Coach in Austin, TX
pros: Great mission, great students. and a ton of (mostly) dedicated people. I wroked my butt off, but my reward was seeing my students excited about getting into college, and it was totally worth it. I learned a lot about working with other people, meeting goals, managing my work, and staying positive. It was fun to make friends from all over the country; I think the Americorps members were from 22 states. Also, Texas winters are great. On reflection, a really good year.
cons: The office can be loud, and sometimes it was hard to stay focused. Some people gripde a lot about not having enough to do, but they're also the ones who slacked off the most, so you have to be careful about who you hang out with. Data entry is a drag, and Americorps salary sucks. To be fair, though, they warned us about the salary and dress code before they hired me, and I made it work.

review_title: Excellent place to serve as an AmeriCorps member
job_title: College Completion Coach in Austin, TX
pros: College Forward is a great place to hone your professional skills and build lasting relationships. The geographic diversity of AmeriCorps members and staff lends to a vast social and professional network after your term of service. Members who advocate for themselves, practice appropriate methods of “managing up” and don’t shy away from leadership opportunities seem to have a better experience overall. Working with students is a lot of fun, and in some cases, will be very rewarding. If you come with an open mind, flexibility and realistic expectations you’ll have a blast. You’ll get out what you put in.
cons: Similar to other AmeriCorps programs, the stipend and insurance plan leave something to be desired. Can emotionally draining/ stressful, will have to work some Saturdays. Not a good position for someone uninterested in qualitative or quantitative data.

pros: Great working experience for those looking to go into higher education or student advising. Managers that care. Team Activities and Offices. Great resource and students who do utilize the service.
cons: They say they want to hear your opinions but really do not.They are already preset in how things are done. IF you keep your head level and don't move the waters too much you will do great and get along with everyone. On the College Completion side the process needs to be revamped. A lot of the students needs have shifted, but we have not adjust our approach. There was little stability during the year I was there (2013-14)

review_title: Loved every minute of College Forward, it was one of the most rewarding experiences in my professional career.
pros: I had a wonderful experience working at College Forward. I was able to build personal relationships with my students and also plan tailored coaching strategies. My manager really encouraged me and gave me valuable feedback regarding my professional development and I was able to use my talents to start new initiatives at this organization. Their team approach was really helpful and I became extremely close to my co-workers. The office has an extreme amount of collaboration and energy which was very helpful.
cons: After working for a large corporation, it was challenging for me to enter the somewhat ambiguous non-profit world but also a great learning experience that gave me opportunities to engage my students and work on creative projects.

pros: The mission, values, and culture of College Forward are spot on.  I am thrilled to come to work everyday and work with people who are as passionate and cooky and I am!  I feel like I am able to make an impact on a social issue I believe in while working in a professional setting.
cons: The hours can be long and there are a lot of competing priorities.  It can sometimes be hard to determine which projects to focus on and which to delegate out due to the nature of the industry.  We all want to help democratize education, but figuring out the best way to achieve that goal, can be difficult.

review_title: Time spent with students is rewarding, time in office is monotonous
job_title: High School Coach (AmeriCorps Member) in Austin, TX
pros: As a high school coach, I loved working directly with my students at their school three days a week. My favorite part was the opportunity to work with students one-on-one, especially when helping them work on college and scholarship essays.
cons: On the days that I was in the College Forward office instead of on site at the school, I often felt like I didn't have enough work to do, which made the day drag on. Meetings would sometimes break up the monotony, but I didn't always feel like we accomplished a lot in large groups.

job_title: Senior College Coach in Houston, TX
pros: Great co-workers. You really bond with the people you work with over the course of 11 months. Still very close friends with my cohort 5 years later. Students were awesome as well.
cons: My Program Manager in the Houston office was awesome but all the management in Austin was questionable. When I worked there, office was VERY far away for everyone. Everyone was based in Houston but they expected a daily commute to Baytown when only 2 people in the office worked in the Baytown schools. So, on average you would put close to a 100 miles a day on your car. It was ridiculous.

pros: Sense of fulfillment that comes with working at any position in the non-profit realm
cons: Compensation is insufficient for employees. Monthly stipend is not enough to pay for costs of living for those counselors who have relocated to Houston area from out of state and cannot live with friends/ family members for little, or no, monthly rent and, therefore, must pay full cost of monthly rent with minimal stipend

review_title: Best way to discover how unskilled and highly educated you are; treated like children despite your age
job_title: ATX Completion Coach in Austin, TX
pros: work hour flexibility, small teams, some limited professional development opportunities, committee involvement, teamworking
cons: lack of transparency in management and those above it, living stipend is ridiculous in Metro ATX, high turnover rate, the future of AmeriCorps isn't too bright, and every year is treated as a blank slate where ideas from previous years are scrapped for "innovation and improvement."

review_title: Great experience, if you make it one.
pros: As an AmeriCorps member, there are great amounts of potential for real-life non-profit management skills in a very attainable position. I worked on the high school side (which I thought was way more fun). Both High School and College "Coaches" also work around the office helping run the organization when they are not with students. Great way to move to Austin (or Houston, but I can't speak to that) and meet a ton of caring people. Admirable mission, one of the leaders in the college access game for revolutionizing "College Completion Services," and the kids they serve are great, of course!!! The management is extremely nice, and can be a great resource if you work it right. If the other reviewer has anything to say about it, maybe I "drank the kool-aid," but that kool-aid left me with a stellar resume and lots of opportunity afterward, so screw it, I'd drink it again!
cons: I think the issues here are the same as with all AmeriCorps programs, especially in Austin: A lot of people join AmeriCorps thinking its going to be so amazing and they are going to change lives every second of every day. It's a real job: some parts suck, just like at every job. There is a lot of time in the office in Manor to do databasing, event planning, meetings. (That stuff is chock-full of transferable skills, though, and for me has been the best job experience.) Keeping busy is necessary in order to not rip your hair out, but if you join a bunch of stuff, its great. A lot of people don't take advantage of the opportunities available for getting involved/professional development and really under-use their experience/end up doing the same thing every day. *Hint: The other reviewer here*  Know that the org is always growing, so things are in a state of flux; if you work here, purposefully talk to your manager often. And if you work in completion, that is a desk job, numbers-driven, no question about it.

job_title: Junior Access Coach in Austin, TX
pros:
I joined College Forward as an Access Coach and enjoyed my year as an AmeriCorps member. College Forward is a pretty progressive nonprofit and I think one can either take that in stride or begrudgingly swelter from the lack of structure. I felt the former. I was given the space to really thrive in the classroom-- create lesson plans that fit my students and their needs. And it showed. Despite my Corps days long behind me, I'm still close with my students! I came in wanting to sincerely create an impact on today's education system, and I left feeling empowered and motivated. The other great thing is coming into AmeriCorps with a support network of other coaches. Having a cohort that wants to make positive change, and who were ready and willing to do the work inspired me. College Forward is really what you make of it and I loved serving. 

Some logistics about College Forward: the vacation days are great (I mean, it doesn't get much  better than this.) Most folks and staff member are free spirited, understanding and sincerely invested in your professional growth. From having someone in the senior management team look over my resume to having folks help Corps members interview for grad school. They do care. One of my best friend now works at an amazing nonprofit in the same college access field! I even had the space to form a curriculum workgroup and essentially, worked it into existence. There's space for critical thinking, creativity and taking on innovative projects.
cons:
Sure, there were some bumps. Do I enjoy having a dress code? No. (I was hyper annoyed with the nazi-esque approach from a particular person about wearing pins) BUT, Is that part of being in a workforce? Yes. First and foremost, I care about education. All other issues were negligible and fell to the back burner. I understand that part of being in a working environment means dressing professional and setting the example for my students. And that's OK with me. An advice for College Forward is bringing on board people who truly care about education, and who have the drive and spirit to carry it out.

Also, Diversity training is needed. Savior complex could be full-blown sometimes. Everybody seemed to take on different "social justice" causes but were unaware of their own privileges (which detracted from the work that we did for our students.)

review_title: Good mission & work, issues w/ organization
job_title: College Access Coach in Houston, TX
pros:
I was a College Access Coach. Working with the students is definitely the best part about this AmeriCorps position. The work that this organization does is beneficial in the communities it serves. The program allows for a lot of freedom for the coach to assist students in whatever way that seems appropriate, based on the needs of the assigned school and students. The environment of so many young people makes for an energetic work environment. It's great to work with people who are motivated to help students succeed.

As AmeriCorps members, this job can be a great launching pad to go into teaching or higher education jobs (admissions, financial aid, academic support services, etc).
cons:
Full time staff seem to have a severe retention issue. The lack of retention of full time staff, as well as AmeriCorps staff, results in the loss of knowledge and skills that may have been developed during a person's time there. Efforts to develop the program by employees are, in a way, short-lived as a result of the lack of retention of all but the higher level staff members; once a person has the experiences from which to build an idea of what could be done better, he or she leaves. 

Speaking of the Houston office, specifically, there is a large disconnect from the primary Austin office. Visits by upper staff members seem more ceremonial than productive or interactive, program resources are not shared effectively between the two offices, and (although it has improved recently) there has been an unfortunate habit of Austin office members to forget about or postpone concern of the needs of the Houston office. The result of these issues, I feel, is that members have less of a voice in the organization and do not feel that they are as equipped to succeed as ATX members might be.

Training for coaches is somewhat brief and could be developed further to increase the knowledge and effectiveness of coaches.

pros: College Forward provided a very unique and accepting organizational culture.  The organization followed a  student-first service model, which made my time employed at College Forward very meaningful.  I was given a lot of autonomy over the direction and implementation of the program I managed, and I was provided with numerous professional development and leadership opportunities.
cons: I struggled to maintain a healthy work/life balance, as there were many opportunities at College Forward I wanted to be involved in.

pros: Far and away, the most valuable and important part of my experience was interacting with my students and creating relationships with them. I also had the honor of having incredibly supportive managers who challenged us, affirmed us, and made sure that we knew that our voices and ideas mattered. This I cannot stress enough was invaluable to me, and one of the only reasons I stayed. My immediate co-workers and team members were an immensely strong support system and network of people who were driven and passionate. I found that many people were interested in or open to learning about social justice, and creating a safe and supportive space. This community looked out for one another, supported each other in times of great sadness and grief,  made sure that everyone was taken care of and even when we disagreed on issues, respected and valued one another. We created a family there, and that I can say was one of my most precious aspects of working at this organization. I would 100% do this again if I were with all of these people again, if I had my students and the community that we had. It was full of love, and couldn't have asked for better people in my life.
cons:
While the managers and AmeriCorps members were dedicated to creating community and seeking justice for our students, people within our senior management overwhelmingly ignored these crucial aspects of our work. While they will tirelessly preach to you about graduation rates, big audacious goals, and what incredible work they are doing, they ignore many of the real issues going on. You cannot address education inequalities and not talk about intersecting forms of oppression; race, gender, socio-economic status and more importantly you can't address these things without also talking about privilege. In other posts you see language like "white savior complex", and that is a repeated pattern for a reason. Conversations we had with senior management about these crucial issues (if had at all) were surface level to say the least, and for the most part suppressed when brought up. Many of my coworkers created groups and shared ideas on how to address different issues facing our students, and though our senior management listened to what we had to say, these proposals seemed to go in one ear and out the other. Despite tireless work done by our managers and AmeriCorps members to follow up, to communicate, to try and build something meaningful for our students, were swiftly dropped, forgotten about, dismissed by senior management. Part of the reason the Corps members protected one another so fiercely was because we certainly did not feel supported by senior management or that they would jump to our defense. There was a strong sense of "us vs. them" within the office, which is never a sentiment you want to feel towards those leading you.

Though change comes slowly and no organization or movement is perfect, no one was expecting that of them. Most of us simply wanted to have a conversation, to be recognized and have our voices heard. Instead, we felt shoved aside, sometimes ignored, other times completely invisible. They (hopefully) made some important changes  surrounding pro-nouns and different hiring practices, but were deceitful when it came to other changes we proposed. They ignored requests for transparency, or placated us by telling us changes, budgets or support were on the way when they simply were not. 

Though senior management cares about the students, they seem to do the opposite of what is in the best interest of the organization. Their is something crumbling within the foundation of the organization, and if not addressed the foundation of this house will continue to rot, will continue to disintegrate and they will continue to witness high rates of staff discontent and turn over.

pros:
Gave you the reigns to develop a project start to finish
Full placed trust in my decision making
Allowed to work in different departments
Rewarded hard work and result-driven outcomes
Worked with amazing students and dedicated employees
Unapologetically advocated for higher education policies
Encouraged personal time off and had PTO
cons: Multiple project management with different authoritative figures

pros: Great place to learn Get a degree
cons: Expensive The parking was oye, qué hora es?

job_title: IT Help Desk in Fullerton, CA
pros: great coworkers, lots of interaction with students and staff, community atmosphere, active
cons: customers can sometimes be difficult, not much opportunity for upward mobility in first couple years

pros: It is Flexible and easy
cons: Unfortunately there is No benefits when you’re part time

pros: In this job, you get to tutor other students in a subject of your choice, for me it was mainly mathematics. I would say by tutoring, you enhance your understanding of a subject, which in itself was a big pro for me. Everyone working here was really nice as well.
cons: I don't think there's many cons to this job. The pay is pretty low, but for a student job at a college I would expect that.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Fullerton, CA
pros: great while going to school
cons: low pay, not many perks

pros: There are so many amazing people that work at Fullerton College to connect with and learn from.
cons: I do not feel there are any downsides. Give it a chance you won't regret it!

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Fullerton, CA
pros: It's an inclusive, welcomed and quiet environment
cons: I don't have anything to add

job_title: English Embedded Tutor in Fullerton, CA
pros: great communication, co-workers are your peers, very friendly and open work environment, lots of independence, decent start pay
cons: pay day once a month, limit on hours worked, mandatory "mentor" meetings, not very many opportunities to move upwards

pros: You gain experience working with students at the community college level.
cons: You only get paid when you tutor. If no students show up, you can't log in hours.

pros:
- great community
- good training
- opportunity to move up
- great flexible schedule for college students
cons: pay isn't the best, but it's part time!

review_title: Great place to attend as a student, even better place to be a part of as an employee!
job_title: Bachelor Degree in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Colleagues care about your success and the students success.
cons: In my opinion there isn't anything bad about this campus.

pros: There has been a lot of support for tutors during covid. Management makes a lot of effort to ensure that tutors have the resources they need to support students. Schedules are fixed so it is very easy for full-time students to fit work into their schedules.
cons: Paychecks arrive once a month instead of bi-weekly.

job_title: Fullerton College Tutor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: flexible hours. will work around your classes

pros:
Strong union representation
excellent faculty resources
Welcoming environment for adjuncts

pros: They work with your class schedule

job_title: Computer Lab Aide in Fullerton, CA
pros: The work is pretty easy, but a little boring

review_title: Great place to work while attending school
pros: Flexible hours and great work environment
cons: Scheduling can be an issue since student employment works around student's education

pros: Great people friendly faces, and a really nice relaxed environment with Great growth and appreciation with compensation

pros: Great experience, great community. Would love it even more if I could work a full time job with benefits and provide more support for students.

Supportive teaching environment 
Equity minded

pros: Flexibility. great people who share like-minded views. Room for growth & great experience. Work life balance. Managament cares about your growth.

job_title: Computer Lab Aide in Fullerton, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities for students, even if you don't attend the college.
cons: No cons noted while working here.

job_title: Musical Theatre Teacher in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Love the campus, students, staff, and faculty. Great environment to work in.
cons: Older campus with some older facilities.

job_title: Technical Engineer in Long Beach, CA
pros: Real nice campus to work in. Great work atmosphere compared to typical corporate environment. Vacation, personal time and holidays are fantastic.
cons: Pay, One of the lowest paid districts in the State. Considering the area its in we should be getting paid a lot more. Its really a trade off of Work/Life balance v good pay.

pros: Get to understand how Fullerton College works and great networking with the faculty. Also, there are special events on campus to get involved in.

pros: Great environment, friendly and helpful colleagues and staff. FC was a great place to work because they treat their adjuncts well. Department chairs were easy to work for and they really encouraged collaboration.

pros: Friendly people, stable environment.  Employees treated with fairness and respect.
